intro: Hemiandra pungens var. incana, commonly known as the woolly hemiandra, is a flowering plant native to the tropical regions of South America. It belongs to the Malvaceae family, which includes hibiscus and cotton, and is characterized by its distinctive, hairy foliage. The plant produces showy, trumpet-shaped flowers that are typically pink or purple in color. It thrives in humid, shaded environments and is often found in moist forest understories. Its unique appearance and ornamental value make it a sought-after plant in horticulture.
